objectID: posts/Fun Stuff/Puns Only Programmers Will Get/index.html
href: posts/Fun Stuff/Puns Only Programmers Will Get/index.html
title: Puns Only Programmers Will Get
text:
Thumbnail


What are the best puns? Definitely the ones only a specific group of people will understand and enjoy. Especially in the era we’re living in, we need to feel like a family and share “inside” jokes with one another. So, let’s take a look at some of the best programming puns we came upon during the pre-summer times.

Why do programmers like dark mode?

Because light attracts bugs.

I used to work as a programmer for autocorrect…

Then they fried me for no raisin.

What do NASA programmers do on the weekends?

They hit the space bar.

Why did the programmer quit his job?

Because he didn’t get arrays.

What was the SNES programmers’ favorite drink?

Sprite

What do programmers do when they’re hungry?

They grab a byte.

Why couldn’t the programmer dance to the song?

Because he didn’t get the… algo-rhythm…

What you call it when computer programmers make fun of each other?

Cyber boolean…

I am now a successful programmer…

But back in the days I was a noobgrammer.

Why do programmers always mix up Halloween and Christmas?

Because Oct 31 equals Dec 25.

Why did the programmer get a huge telephone bill?

Because his program was CALLING a lot of subroutines.

What do Spanish programmers code in?

Sí ++

Which way did the programmer go?

He went data way!

Why was the programmer always running into walls?

He couldn’t see sharp.

How programmers curse?

Oh shift!

Why do programmers make good politicians?

Their goto is to switch statements.

How did the programmer lose weight?

He switched to a byte-sized diet.

I almost bought a huge library out of old computer programming books…

But the ascii price was way too high.

What’s a Jedi’s favorite programming language?

JabbaScript…



Want to learn programming and become an expert?
If you’re serious about learning Programming and getting a job as a Developer, I highly encourage you to enroll in my programming courses for Python, JavaScript, Data Science and Web Development.
Don’t waste your time following disconnected, outdated tutorials. I can teach you all that you need to kickstart your career.
Contact me at +256771754118 or jumashafara@proton.me

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Thumbnail
Here’s a list of the most popular softwares used by the hackers in the Emmy and Golden Globe award winning drama/thriller series Mr. Robot.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#kali-linux
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#kali-linux
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Kali Linux
Kali Linux is a Linux distro made for security researchers for penetration testing, but is also used by hackers since it is jam packed with hacking tools. It is regularly featured in Mr. Robot since it is the hackers’ operating system of choice.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#tor-browser
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#tor-browser
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Tor Browser
Tor Browser is widely considered to be the best anonymizing tool out there. It will make your Internet activity very hard to trace, which fsociety takes advantage of when Trenton in season 2, episode 8 uploads a leaked FBI conference call about illegal mass surveillance to Vimeo using Tor Browser.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#raspberry-pi
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#raspberry-pi
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Raspberry Pi
Raspberry Pi is a small, programmable computer board designed to teach children about computer science. It is also favourite among hobbyists and programmers due to its low-cost, versatility and simplicity. In season 1, episode 5 Elliot installs a Raspberry Pi into Steel Mountain’s climate control system so that fsociety at a later point in time can remotely raise the temperature in the storage room where Evil Corp’s tape backups are stored, resulting in the backups of the records of a significant portion of the US’ consumer debt being destroyed.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#proton-mail
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#proton-mail
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Proton Mail
ProtonMail is a secure, end-to-end encrypted e-mail service based in Switzerland that is used by Elliot in season 1, episode 8. The team behind Mr. Robot researched secure e-mail services to the extent that they actually contacted the ProtonMail developers and asked if it was possible for users to monitor their own e-mail activity in ProtonMail. The ProtonMail developers liked the idea of account access logs so much that they ended up implementing it in their v2.0 release of ProtonMail.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#pycharm
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#pycharm
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
PyCharm
PyCharm is a Python and Django IDE (Integrated Developer Environment), which is a type of code editor software. It is used by Trenton in season 1, episode 4.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#bluesniff
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#bluesniff
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Bluesniff
Bluesniff is a Bluetooth device discovery tool. In season 1, episode 6 Elliot uses Bluesniff in combination with btscanner and Metasploit when he connects to the computer in a nearby police car via a MultiBlue Bluetooth USB Dongle to compromise a prison’s network in order to break a drug dealer called Vera out of prison.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#btscanner
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#btscanner
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
btscanner
btscanner is a tool that is included in Kali Linux that extracts as much information as possible about Bluetooth devices without having to pair. In season 1, episode 6 Elliot uses btscanner in combination with Bluesniff and Metasploit when he connects to the computer in a nearby police car using a MultiBlue Bluetooth USB Dongle to compromise a prison’s network in order to break a drug dealer called Vera out of prison.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#mozilla-firefox
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#mozilla-firefox
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Mozilla Firefox
Elliot uses Firefox as his default web browser. Trenton uses Firefox in season 2, episode 8.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#vlc-media-player
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#vlc-media-player
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
VLC Media Player
VLC Media Player was used in season 2, episode 4 when Elliot and Darlene watched a VHS rip of the fake horror movie Careful Massacre of the Bourgeoisie together. VLC is also used in season 2, episode 8 when fsociety preview the video they are about to upload a leaked FBI conference call about illegal mass surveillance.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#µtorrent
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#µtorrent
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
µTorrent
In season 2, episode 4 Darlene was downloading a VHS rip of the fake horror movie Careful Massacre of the Bourgeoisie using µTorrent.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#flexispy
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#flexispy
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
FlexiSPY
FlexiSPY is a spyware software for Android, iOS and BlackBerry that lets the user monitor all activities on the victims phone. In season 1, episode 3 Tyrell Wellick covertly installs it on a co-worker’s Android phone in order to get access to secret information about who is going to be the next chief technology officer of Evil Corp.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#kingoroot
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#kingoroot
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
KingoRoot
Kingo Root is used by Tyrell Wellick in season 1, episode 3 to root a co-worker’s Android phone so that he can covertly install the FlexiSPY spyware on the phone in order to get access to secret information about who is going to be the next chief technology officer of Evil Corp.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#kvm-kernel-based-virtual-machine
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#kvm-kernel-based-virtual-machine
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine)
KVM is a hypervisor, which is a software that can run other operating systems via virtual machines. Elliot uses KVM to virtualize Windows 7 inside of Kali Linux. In season 1, episode 6 Elliot uses KVM to run Metasploit and Metapreter and in season 1, episode 8 he uses KVM to run DeepSound.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#metasploit
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#metasploit
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Metasploit
Metasploit Framework is a software included in Kali Linux that makes it easier to discover vulnerabilities in networks for penetration testers. Meterpreter is one of several hundreds of payloads that can be run in the Metasploit Framework and it is used in season 1, episode 6. In season 1, episode 6 Elliot uses Metasploit Framwork and Metapreter in combination with btscanner and Bluesniff when he connects to the computer in a nearby police car via a MultiBlue Bluetooth USB Dongle to compromise a prison’s network in order to break a drug dealer called Vera out of prison.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#framaroot
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#framaroot
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
Framaroot
Framaroot - called RooterFrame in the show - is used by Tyrell Wellick in season 1, episode 3 to root a co-worker’s Android phone so that he can covertly install the FlexiSPY spyware on the phone in order to get access to secret information about who is going to be the next chief technology officer of Evil Corp.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#supersu
href: posts/Software/All Software Used in Mr. Robot/index.html#supersu
title: All Software used in Mr. Robot
text:
SuperSU
SuperSU is an app that managed superuser privileges on rooted Android phones. In season 1, episode 3 Tyrell Wellick covertly installs FlexiSPY - which uses SuperSU to give itself superuser access - on a co-worker’s Android phone in order to get access to secret information about who is going to be the next chief technology officer of Evil Corp.
crumbs: All Software used in Mr. Robot

objectID: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html
href: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html
title: To 5 Operating Systems
text:
Thumbnail
Operating systems are the backbone of modern computing, providing the fundamental software foundation for computers, smartphones, servers, and more. Here’s a comprehensive overview of five prominent operating systems that have made significant impacts in various domains.

objectID: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#windows
href: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#windows
title: To 5 Operating Systems
text:
Windows

Overview
Developed by Microsoft, Windows is one of the most widely used operating systems across PCs, servers, and embedded systems. Known for its user-friendly interface and extensive software compatibility, Windows offers a variety of versions tailored for different devices and use cases.


Features

GUI: Graphical User Interface for intuitive navigation.
Compatibility: Broad support for software and hardware.
Security: Regular updates and security features.

objectID: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#macos
href: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#macos
title: To 5 Operating Systems
text:
macOS

Overview
Exclusive to Apple’s hardware, macOS offers a sleek and intuitive user experience. It is known for its stability, design aesthetics, and seamless integration with other Apple devices and services.


Features

Integration: Seamless integration with other Apple devices.
Performance: Optimized for Mac hardware.
Security: Built-in encryption and privacy features.

objectID: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#linux
href: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#linux
title: To 5 Operating Systems
text:
Linux

Overview
Linux is an open-source operating system available in various distributions (distros), catering to diverse user needs. Its flexibility, stability, and robustness have made it a favorite among developers, server administrators, and tech enthusiasts.


Features

Open Source: Community-driven development and customization.
Variety: Diverse distributions catering to different needs.
Stability: Known for reliability and performance.

objectID: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#android
href: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#android
title: To 5 Operating Systems
text:
Android

Overview
Developed by Google, Android is the leading operating system for mobile devices globally. Its open-source nature, customizable interface, and extensive app ecosystem have made it a dominant force in the mobile market.


Features

Customization: Ability to personalize interface and features.
App Ecosystem: Extensive library of applications.
Integration: Seamless integration with Google services.

objectID: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#iosipados
href: posts/Software/Top 5 Operating Systems/index.html#iosipados
title: To 5 Operating Systems
text:
iOS/iPadOS

Overview
Exclusive to Apple’s mobile devices, iOS and iPadOS are renowned for their smooth performance, security features, and seamless integration within the Apple ecosystem.


Features

Performance: Smooth and efficient operation on Apple devices.
Security: Robust security measures and privacy controls.
Ecosystem Integration: Seamless integration with other Apple devices.

In conclusion, these operating systems showcase diversity in terms of architecture, platform support, and features, catering to the varied needs of users across different devices and industries.
